context: [1] The specific role of nitric oxide in tumor biology is not established. [2] A broad spectrum of activities has been assigned to either the physiology or the pathophysiology of nitric oxide in tumor cells (for a review, see Ref. ). [3] Low output of nitric oxide has been correlated with increased blood flow and new blood vessels feeding the tumor area . [4] In addition, the generation of nitric oxide by tumor cells may inhibit the activation and proliferation or may increase the apoptosis of surrounding lymphocytes that can account for the immune suppression accompanying tumor growth (data not shown). [5] Furthermore, high intratumoral output of nitric oxide could inhibit the activation of caspases and therefore antagonizes the pro-apoptotic signals . [6] However, the opposite effect has also been observed in many other systems whereby the generation of high output of nitric oxide, either by iNOS induction or by the use of NO donors, inhibits tumor growth and metastasis . [7] Therefore, the final outcome of NO-mediated effects would be determined by many factors including the local concentration and sources of nitric oxide and the presence of reactive molecules that might redirect the redox status in the tumor cell.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, nitric oxide (NO) plays a complex role in tumor biology, influencing apoptosis in various ways. Low levels of NO are associated with increased blood flow and tumor growth, while high levels can inhibit caspase activation, thereby reducing apoptosis in surrounding lymphocytes. Conversely, high NO output can also promote apoptosis in certain contexts, indicating that the relationship between NO and apoptosis is context-dependent and influenced by local concentrations and reactive molecules present in the tumor environment.
